title: Hezekiah's Deliverance
shortSummary: This chapter recounts King Hezekiah's preparation and trust in God during the Assyrian siege led by Sennacherib. Despite the overwhelming threat and enemy blasphemy, Hezekiah's faith and prayer result in divine intervention and deliverance, highlighting God's power to save His people. The chapter also records Hezekiah's later pride and humility, demonstrating the ongoing need for repentance.
timeline: c. 701 BC - Assyrian Siege of Jerusalem during Hezekiah's reign

keyCharacters.name: Hezekiah
keyCharacters.description: King of Judah who leads the defense of Jerusalem, trusts in God, and prays for deliverance during the Assyrian siege.

keyCharacters.name: Sennacherib
keyCharacters.description: King of Assyria who invades Judah and mocks the God of Israel, laying siege to Jerusalem.

keyCharacters.name: Isaiah
keyCharacters.description: Prophet of God who supports Hezekiah through prayer and counsel during the crisis.

definitions.definition: A terraced structure or fortification in Jerusalem, repaired by Hezekiah to strengthen the city’s defenses.
A phrase referring to human strength or power, contrasted with reliance on God’s power.
Elevated sites used for pagan worship, which Hezekiah removed to restore proper worship of the LORD.
A messenger of God; in this chapter, the angel executes divine judgment against the Assyrian army.

outline.heading: Hezekiah’s Preparations Against Assyria
outline.description: Hezekiah fortifies Jerusalem by stopping water sources, repairing walls, and encouraging his people to trust in God rather than human strength.

outline.heading: Sennacherib’s Threats and Blasphemy
outline.description: The Assyrian king sends messages mocking Hezekiah and the God of Israel, attempting to intimidate Jerusalem’s inhabitants and undermine their faith.

outline.heading: Divine Deliverance and Assyrian Defeat
outline.description: Hezekiah and Isaiah pray, and God sends an angel who destroys the Assyrian army, leading to Sennacherib’s shameful retreat and death.

outline.heading: Hezekiah’s Illness, Pride, and Humbling
outline.description: Hezekiah becomes gravely ill and prays for healing, but later his pride brings God’s wrath until he humbles himself and averts judgment.

outline.heading: Hezekiah’s Wealth and Legacy
outline.description: Hezekiah accumulates great riches and fortifies the city’s resources; the chapter concludes with his death and the succession of his son Manasseh.

application: Trust in God’s power rather than relying solely on human strength when facing life’s challenges.
Respond to opposition and spiritual attacks with prayer and faith, following Hezekiah’s example.
Recognize the danger of pride after blessings and practice humility to maintain a right relationship with God.
Prepare wisely and act courageously while resting in God’s sovereign protection.

keyVerses.text: With him is an arm of flesh; but with us is the LORD our God to help us, and to fight our battles. And the people rested themselves upon the words of Hezekiah king of Judah.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the contrast between human strength and divine help, encouraging believers to trust in God’s power.

keyVerses.text: And the LORD sent an angel, which cut off all the mighty men of valour, and the leaders and captains in the camp of the king of Assyria. So he returned with shame of face to his own land. And when he was come into the house of his god, they that came forth of his own bowels slew him there with the sword.
keyVerses.significance: This verse demonstrates God’s direct intervention to save His people and bring judgment on their enemies.

keyVerses.text: Notwithstanding Hezekiah humbled himself for the pride of his heart, both he and the inhabitants of Jerusalem, so that the wrath of the LORD came not upon them in the days of Hezekiah.
keyVerses.significance: This verse teaches the importance of humility and repentance in averting God’s judgment.
